meeting_annotations.transcript: Well the most near and dear to my heart is pet because we get um the sensitivity from the the you know tracer and then you know very low background so it becomes sort of a chemistry and probe development question. meeting_annotations.speaker: mark selimyer (UPenn)
meeting_annotations.transcript: And so you know to Ping's question you get around some of the cell death by engineering a gene in that's going to be only expressed in live cells as he said very nicely.

meeting_annotations.speaker: mark selimyer (UPenn)
meeting_annotations.transcript: And you think about how pre-clinical imaging was changed by the ciphers and you know microscopy was changed by GFP like it would be phenomenal to have a reporter gene that's non-immunogenic small blah blah blah to be able to get into a clinical you know scenario.

meeting_annotations.speaker: mark selimyer (UPenn)
meeting_annotations.transcript: I think the other one that we should be as a group thinking about and we're less probably experienced even what everyone has sort of said but um is is in ultrasound because there if you're going to get clinical translation you're going to get pretty good depth of penetration of the of the modality.

meeting_annotations.speaker: mark selimyer (UPenn)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Micro bubbles yeah that get that basically again borrowed from a different part of nature the buoyancy operon of bacteria and engineered that into um or of algae the buoyancy operon of algae and engineered it into bacteria to be able to see bacteria expressing those.

meeting_annotations.speaker: mark selimyer (UPenn)
meeting_annotations.transcript: And also took that same genetic operon and put it into mammalian cells so that you can put your ultrasound probe on there and then see scattering of air and gas bubbles that the cell is producing itself. And so I've always wondered sort of why um you know people haven't sort of focused on um you know contrast like instead of contrast injectable contrast dies but contrast lipids or whatever that would be labeling single cells or that would be I don't know we we talked about actually like injecting iron or like soaking the cells in iron and then trying to chase them around in in our CT one time but of course I didn't have the bandwidth to do that.
